story:
ABOUT US

Tapona International, a registered social entrepreneurship in Kenya, is excited to launch its Eggpreneurship Campaign to fund economic development and nutritional support for families in poverty in Kenya. The campaign is supported online through Kansas City musical donations and eggpreneurship perks. 

Six musicians from the Kansas City region have partnered alongside of us donating their time and music to bring change to the people of Machakos County. The initial launch of the Indiegogo Campaign will occur at Blackdog Coffeehouse in Lenexa, Kansas.

International collaborators in global health have developed Tapona's first initiative to increase maternal economic stability and to provide child nutrition. With a successful campaign mothers will be supplied egg-laying poultry as a means to generate money and provide protein for their children. This foundation will be laid for further initiatives in early childhood development, parent education, and family support. Recently begun in January 2015, Tapona's goal through its work and partnership is to engage, encourage, and empower.

HOW DOES IT WORK?

  1. Household Income. To engage eggpreneurs in a more efficient, profitable, and sustainable model for consistent income at their rural homes

  2. Protein. To encourage healthier growth for small children with mothers working right at home to be present for their baby’s needs

  3. Knowledge. To empower families and communities for a significant reduction in child malnutrition through nutritional knowledge 

 

WHAT IS THE GOAL?

Women Eggpreneur is an egg farming social venture started to financially empower mothers with children five years old and younger in rural Kenya. Our goal of $17,000 will fund all necessary start-up and infrastructure to launch Eggpreneurship for 20 women and their children. All funds go toward the project on the ground to fight poverty, unemployment, and child malnutrition.


WHERE IS THE PROJECT TODAY?

A year of networking with people in Kenya, the USA, and Canada has being met with excitement and approval. There is a strong desire from the local women, village elders, and religious leaders to be involved in the project. A local veterinarian has confirmed that the Women Eggpreneur model is a suitable solution for women in Machakos. The founder, Matthew Dickson, has been encouraged by the response.  He has opened an office in Machakos County, and his team is currently building a chicken house to raise the first batch of egg-layers, which will be ready this summer for trained mothers to receive. On the business front, he has contacted local egg buyers to understand their egg production demands and secure contracts. Pieces are coming together, and we invite you to join us too!

Please fight with us against poverty and malnutrition in Machakos, Kenya.

http://www.taponainternational.com

PARTNERING ARTISTS


CALVIN ARSENIA
http://www.calvinarsenia.com

Calvin Arsenia uses music to tell stories of the heart. With influences ranging from Lauryn Hill to Andrea Bocelli, Arsenia inspires audiences with his whimsical songs and soulful style. Since his solo debut in 2010, he has written, produced, and recorded 8 EPs featuring guitar, piano, and folk harp as his main instruments. Most notably though, is Arsenia’s passionate vocals and broad vocal range. Stay tuned for his next EP, Cardiac, which is due to release Summer 2015.



MARLEY ALLENBRAND
http://www.facebook.com/MarleyAnnAllenbrand/

Marley is a seasoned musician, starting as a drummer from an early age thanks to Hanson, and working with guitar shortly thereafter. She draws influence from Ellie Goulding, Lucy Rose, and Carol King. She released her first EP, "Let Go, Move On" in April of 2014.


NOBLE GIANT
http://www.andersross.com/noblegiant

An entrepreneur, musician, photographer, cook, encourager, and friend,  Andrew Ross, aka, Noble Giant is currently in the studio completing, "Washed White", the first installment of this journey, after 10 years of writing. He grew up listening to an array of music, drawing inspiration from Classical and Soul, Jazz and Big Band, as well as Electronic and Indie Folk. His style has been compared to Beirut, Iron & Wine, Bon Iver, and Jeff Pianki. The tentative release is late Summer of 2015.


KAHEALANI
http://www.facebook.com/kahealanimusic/

Combining wistful melodies and whimsical lyrics, Kahealani creates music that is vulnerable and sincere. Her carefully chosen words are emphasized by ethereal vocals reminiscent of Regina Spektor. An acoustic style similar to that of The Civil Wars or Kina Grannis contributes to an overall poetic and lilting sound. Kahealani is currently working on her first album and hopes to release it by 2016.


STATICFINGERS
https://www.soundcloud.com/staticfigers

StaticFingers has a knack for bridging musical gaps. With similar vocal styling to The Smiths and Neutral Milk Hotel, he is also influenced by Brandon Flowers of The Killers. He nestles his 90s styled vocals with an electronic background creating a music definitely worth keeping an eye out for.


LYDIA HESTON

A free spirit and an old soul, Lydia finds great joy in creating elegant music on the classic black and white keys of a piano. She has a soulful voice and a gut-wrenching passion that cuts to the heart of the issue. Her piano pieces are inspired by classical work and modern emotional compositions. She considers her music to be rather simple. But, would you not agree, the greatest joys in life are often the simplest?
story_txt:
ABOUT US
Tapona International, a registered social entrepreneurship in Kenya, is excited to launch its Eggpreneurship Campaign to fund economic development and nutritional support for families in poverty in Kenya. The campaign is supported online through Kansas City musical donations and eggpreneurship perks. Six musicians from the Kansas City region have partnered alongside of us donating their time and music to bring change to the people of Machakos County. The initial launch of the Indiegogo Campaign will occur at Blackdog Coffeehouse in Lenexa, Kansas.
International collaborators in global health have developed Tapona's first initiative to increase maternal economic stability and to provide child nutrition. With a successful campaign  mothers will be supplied egg-laying poultry as a means to generate money and provide protein for their children. This foundation will be laid for further initiatives in early childhood development, parent education, and family support. Recently begun in January 2015, Tapona's goal through its work and partnership is to engage, encourage, and empower.
HOW DOES IT WORK?

Household Income. To engage eggpreneurs in a more efficient, profitable, and sustainable model for consistent income at their rural homes
Protein. To encourage healthier growth for small children with mothers working right at home to be present for their baby’s needs
Knowledge. To empower families and communities for a significant reduction in child malnutrition through nutritional knowledge 

 WHAT IS THE GOAL?Women
 Eggpreneur is an egg farming social venture started to financially 
empower mothers with children five years old and younger in rural Kenya. Our goal of $17,000 will fund all necessary start-up and infrastructure to launch Eggpreneurship for 20 women and their children. All funds go toward the project on the ground to fight poverty, unemployment, and child malnutrition.WHERE IS THE PROJECT TODAY?A year of networking with people in Kenya, the 
USA, and Canada has being met with excitement and approval. There is a 
strong desire from the local women, village elders, and religious 
leaders to be involved in the project. A local veterinarian has confirmed that the Women Eggpreneur model is a suitable solution for 
women in Machakos. The founder, Matthew Dickson, has been encouraged by the response. 
 He has opened an office in Machakos County, and his team is currently 
building a chicken house to raise the first batch of egg-layers, which 
will be ready this summer for trained mothers to receive. On the 
business front, he has contacted local egg buyers to understand their 
egg production demands and secure contracts. Pieces are coming together, and we invite you to join us too!Please fight with us against poverty and malnutrition in Machakos, Kenya.http://www.taponainternational.comPARTNERING ARTISTSCALVIN ARSENIAhttp://www.calvinarsenia.comCalvin Arsenia uses music to tell stories of the heart. With influences ranging from Lauryn Hill to Andrea Bocelli, Arsenia inspires audiences with his whimsical songs and soulful style. Since his solo debut in 2010, he has written, produced, and recorded 8 EPs featuring guitar, piano, and folk harp as his main instruments. Most notably though, is Arsenia’s passionate vocals and broad vocal range. Stay tuned for his next EP, Cardiac, which is due to release Summer 2015.MARLEY ALLENBRANDhttp://www.facebook.com/MarleyAnnAllenbrand/Marley is a seasoned musician, starting as a drummer from an early age thanks to Hanson, and working with guitar shortly thereafter. She draws influence from Ellie Goulding, Lucy Rose, and Carol King. She released her first EP, "Let Go, Move On" in April of 2014.NOBLE GIANThttp://www.andersross.com/noblegiantAn entrepreneur, musician, photographer, cook, encourager, and friend,  Andrew Ross, aka, Noble Giant is currently in the studio completing, "Washed White", the first installment of this journey, after 10 years of writing. He grew up listening to an array of music, drawing inspiration from Classical and Soul, Jazz and Big Band, as well as Electronic and Indie Folk. His style has been compared to Beirut, Iron & Wine, Bon Iver, and Jeff Pianki. The tentative release is late Summer of 2015.KAHEALANIhttp://www.facebook.com/kahealanimusic/Combining wistful melodies and whimsical lyrics, Kahealani creates music that is vulnerable and sincere. Her carefully chosen words are emphasized by ethereal vocals reminiscent of Regina Spektor. An acoustic style similar to that of The Civil Wars or Kina Grannis contributes to an overall poetic and lilting sound. Kahealani is currently working on her first album and hopes to release it by 2016.STATICFINGERShttps://www.soundcloud.com/staticfigers
StaticFingers has a knack for bridging musical gaps. With similar vocal styling to The Smiths and Neutral Milk Hotel, he is also influenced by Brandon Flowers of The Killers. He nestles his 90s styled vocals with an electronic background creating a music definitely worth keeping an eye out for.LYDIA HESTONA free spirit and an old soul, Lydia finds great joy in creating elegant music on the classic black and white keys of a piano. She has a soulful voice and a gut-wrenching passion that cuts to the heart of the issue. Her piano pieces are inspired by classical work and modern emotional compositions. She considers her music to be rather simple. But, would you not agree, the greatest joys in life are often the simplest?

story:
Short Summary-

Labs for Liberty is a 501(c)(3) nonprofit that provides service dogs & mountain retreats for Veterans of the United States Military, free of charge.


This organization runs as the product of a fire, a flame

that burns inside of each of us that is associated with its cause. The burning desire 

and call to action to save those who have fought protecting our freedoms. Just as 

they have fought, cried, bled, suffered, smiled, laughed, and persevered as will we 

while on this road to end the 22 Veteran suicides per day. We will mirror the 

philosophy of the US Navy Seals in that "WE will NEVER quit, WE will persevere and 

thrive on adversity. If knocked down. WE will get back up. WE will draw on every 

remaining ounce of strength to protect our Veterans and accomplish our mission. 

WE are NEVER out of the fight." Together we stand undivided, and unbeatable.

 - Jacob Nold, Labs for Liberty Director of Philanthropy


Here's the story-

Everyday 22 Veterans commit suicide, that's 1 every 65 minutes, and 8,030 per year! That's more than the War on Terror since 2001 which has claimed 6,717 American lives.


worthywarrior.org

Mission-

 1) Gift custom trained service dogs to Veterans.

2) Provide free vacation lodging at Liberty Outpost for Veterans and their families.

Ultimately, our missions serve to improve the quality of the lives of the Warrior and their family, while potentially saving lives.


The Impact-

Hearing the stories and seeing the impact that our dogs have and will have on their Veteran is what brings a smile to our faces and tears to our eyes. They were called to duty, had a passion for what they did, and risked their life. To be able to gift them with a loyal companion who will calm their nerves, wake them from nightmares, and put a smile on their face with their wiggling tail and bright eyes is what we're all about.

Service dogs have been shown to decrease the symptoms of PTSD and improve overall quality of life, both psychologically and physically.  A few quotes from our veterans will enlighten you to their incomparable value.

Our Pups with their Veterans 

-Matt & Willis - California 

"Thanks for giving me my life back. I already consider you guys extended family."



-Jim & Spanky - Nebraska

"Spanky is an expert at (pulling off) socks and will retrieve almost anything we ask him to pick up. He is trained to bring me my clothes in the morning and he is very happy to help. Spanky seems to know when I am in pain and need the most help and he is never more then a few steps away from me.  Thank you for the gift you have given me."

-James & Samson – Missouri

"I had a difficult night last night. I awoke as usual with troubling thoughts and memories. As I became more awake and aware I realized that Samson was laying up next to me with his face next to mine. All my troubles went away and I loved on Samson. He is my "Guardian Angel" and faithful friend. Thank you so much."

-Anthony & Penny - Missouri        

"The day you called me to tell me I didn't have a choice in Penny Poo being my pup forever changed my life. July and August are the absolute worst times of year for me. I have many battle scars from those months.  Prior to you calling me, my grip had already started slipping again. Since I always have to be strong for others I don't want them to see me hurt or struggle. So I began to try and hide it from others. I began to doubt myself, increased my drinking to mask the pain, and pull away from others. I was falling fast and hard.  July 5th you gave me the single most important tool I needed to stop my fall.  Oh Penny Poo......  Having her for only 3 months has broken my fall too many times to count.


What We Need & What You Get-

- Labs for Liberty placed their first service pup July 5, 2014.

-Official 501(c)3 status was granted in December, 2014.  

Labs for Liberty has been funded by the Nold family, with a few outside donations to fund puppies.  With this funding, and all volunteer staff, to date we have placed 4 pups with their veterans, have 6 in foster care/training, and have another 10 veterans in the application process. 

-Our goal is to place 25 service pups with their veterans in the next 12 months.  

-Increase the number of service pups placed yearly by at least 10.  

To help achieve that goal, we are sponsoring a service dog training class, taught pro bono by John Lopez (retired army combat engineer now master dog trainer) of Standing OBEYtion, in Rogersville, MO.  John will educate 12 veterans on how to train service dogs.

To accomplish the above goals, our budget is $90,000. 

The second half to our mission is the Liberty Outpost, a guesthouse on our 27 acre property overlooking the beautiful Morgan Valley in Morgan, Utah. Liberty Outpost will provide free vacation lodging for veterans and their families.  

Our yearly operating budget for Liberty Outpost is $10,000.

As all individuals involved with Labs for Liberty donate their time, approximately 98% of the funds will go directly to benefit our Veterans


PERKS-


Puppy Calendar



Puppies & Patriots Calendar


Labs for Liberty T-shirt


Header Grey & Traditional Black

Liberty Outpost Stay & Sponsor a Veterans' Stay


Risks & Challenges

The need for well-trained service dogs is great. The greatest challenge we face is financing, as everyone that works for us is strictly a volunteer. There is no lack of individuals, actually Veterans, who themselves are willing to learn to train service dogs for other veterans. There is no lack of puppies, as we work closely with a reputable breeder and will be breeding labs ourselves. And, most unfortunately, there is no lack of individuals in desperate need of a well-trained service dog to help them reintegrate into and function in civilian life.

We are committed to giving our time, and whatever funds we can, to support our mission. Serving our veterans is our privilege and our passion. We hope to share that privilege and passion with other Americans.


Our Team:


Make our mission YOUR mission and share what we are doing with everyone you know! Together we can save lives!


Our Partners-

story:
4/15/2015 - A sincere thank you for those who have taken notice of this post and shared it with others. An additional thank you for the $70 that has been contributed thus far. I was beginning to lose hope after 20 days! $50 has been forwarded to Appiah and his siblings to help out so far.

I know I was shooting for $5,000 and I am aware that may not happen, it is okay. What matters most is that this young man and his siblings see that people do care so that he can stay inspired and continue being a positive inspiration also to his siblings.  Again, thank you so much for what you have done and for what others may do.


Appiah is the tall one in the back.
If you wish to reference this young mans character and see what I see you are free to see his Facebook profile... make a friend as well, he has a heart of gold

Appiah Cytras https://www.facebook.com/profile.php?id=100005653004723
I first came to know Appiah about 2 months ago on Facebook. Through a church page he knows my mother and therefore he found me. I had only previously spoken to him once due to my very busy schedule.

In this time I have been watching his Facebook profile and have learned a bit about him, I learned a bit more from my mother too but I will get to that.

Appiah is 20 years old and lives in Ghana Africa, he has 4 brothers and sisters. This was all I knew. Appiah is very (and I mean extremely) religious. It is all you see on his timeline. Scripture versus, prayers for people he knows and always viewing life as a gift with blessings in store for those who have faith.

Through my mother I learned that he alone takes care of his 4 brothers and sisters. I did not know the reason for this or where his parents were. He had never written anything asking for sympathy or help, only prayer for the well being of his family and food on the table.

I was truly moved by this young mans heart and had to find out what his story was. I messaged him literally asking him "Tell me your story, where are your parents? What is your life like?"

I will quote - "Hello brother William, hope all is well over there and I am sorry for not replying you earlier, I was busy at church all yesterday, I have 4 younger siblings including me in which I am the oldest, we lost our parents 8y ears ago, this coming November will be 9 years when they were on their way to church crusade in the next town. Since then we went to live at the orphanage home called 'Step by Step' orphanage home but when I got to 20 years I leave there because I am not allow to live there. So I now live with a friend and now I have all my siblings here who are not living in the orphanage home anymore due to some problems at the orphanage home, and also I am a student and I am now in senior high school level 2."

He is 20 years old and caring for his siblings on his own, he is finishing school, they are struggling and like I said... I looked at his entire timeline dating back to 2012 and have not seen one request for help or sympathy.

I am not the 'save the world" kind of person, but this young man touched my heart and I want to do something for him to help. To show him that prayers can be answered and that His faith is powerful and that people who do not even know him care. I applaud his courage and am asking you to see in him what I see and have the heart to reach out and help.

I will not be taking the lump sum and sending it to him however. I will hold it in an account and will send it to him as needed. Kind of like a trust fund that neither he nor anyone else can get in to. It is for the sole purpose of putting food on the table, keeping a roof on his head and to help clothe his brothers and sisters.

The siblings names are -

Jethro Agyemang 13 years
Gabriel Agyemang 14 years
Israel Agyemang 11 years  
Lordina Agyemang 10 years

I will include a picture of them all together later.

This is my effort to try to be a big brother to a young man who IS the big brother, the mother and the father to his younger brothers and sisters.

story:
Overview

Creating a Profound Sense of Community is a movement rising up in the wake of recent tragedies inFerguson MO, Madison WI, Los Angeles CA, North Charleston SC--and now Baltimore, MD. We have initiated this project to:

·Dismantle the barriers between law enforcement and the communities they serve that have contributed to the use of excessive force and violence in our communities

·Create partnerships in our communities, and with law enforcement to generate trust, respect and honor to work together powerfully toward viable and acceptable solutions

The goal of this campaign is to raise $75,000 for Town Hall meetings and the Public Education Campaign.

Background

Who we are: We are Omar Henderson and Kareem Ali, longtime residents of metropolitan Washington DC and partners in a media company. We are parents and grandparents, and our deepest aspiration is that our children—and all of the children in our communities—are safe and grow up to become adults with productive and meaningful lives. We were profoundly frustrated with the news of the Grand Jury’s failure to bring forward an indictment of the police officer who shot and killed unarmed Michael Brown in Ferguson, MO. Yet out of this sense of helplessness, we committed to do something about this. We could no longer sit on the sidelines and complain and we started Creating a Profound Sense of Community.

Why this project: We are all too familiar with the abuse, injury, sense of victimization, even death from the use of excessive force in encounters with police. At the same time, police officers we know say how dangerous it is patrolling the streets in high crime areas. In Baltimore, more than seven police officers were injured in the riots following the funeral of latest police violence victim, Freddie Gray. The relationship between law enforcement and the African Americans is laden with fear. The media coverage exploits that emotion and sensationalizes the situation, leaving us with a “well, what can we really do?”

What We Believe: Many policy suggestions are flying around, from heightened accountability of law enforcement agencies, revision of regulations governing police conduct, expanding the use of bodycams, and more. While all these proposals hit at much needed reform, how do we move forward, in this climate of mistrust, anger, and sorrow on a massive community level? We hear of marches being organized to protest police violence and, while we truly want our voices to be heard, the ensuing rioting overshadows our voices. What happens after the destruction from the rioting? How are we going to forge a lasting capacity to bring peace to our streets?

We firmly believe that partnership between law enforcement and our communities is a necessity. Perhaps together we can build trust, get to know one another on a deeper level and work together powerfully to keep our streets safe. A climate of cooperation can help lay the foundation on which new policies and regulations governing police conduct can be built. AND we have to look at ourselves! Who are we that this goes on in our communities? All of us need to take ownership of our collective future. Creating a Profound Sense of Community is an expression of our concern and compassion for people here and around the world.

When we can see one another as human beings with fundamentally the same interests, we can work together instead of resorting to violence out of fear and anger. Relationships can be transformed and paradigm shifts will occur inside of new possibilities for collaboration. 

Building a Team:  We reached out to an international expert on conflict resolution (featured in the national best-selling book, The Three Laws of Performance by Steve Zaffron) who is a well-known leader in communication training and personal development, Ms. Jean Lloyd. In 25 years as a change maker she has touched over 250,000 lives through her work with corporations, non-profit organizations and individuals. She calls herself a cultural architect instigating change and leading difficult conversations that create cultures where everyone wins.

Upon receiving our invitation to serve, Ms. Jean Lloyd enthusiastically accepted our request to facilitate the town hall meetings. “No one has asked for my help to take on anything of this magnitude and importance. I had to accept.” (For a fuller bio on Ms. Lloyd go to http://jeanlloyd.com)

Subsequently we reached out to known experts, professionals, and community leaders and formed teams around video and broadcast production, strategic planning, finance, fundraising and non-profit management, marketing and promotion.

The Project

The core activities: Creating a Profound Sense of Community (CAPSOC) will host four “town hall’ style meetings to bring community and law enforcement together.  CAPSOC meetings will broadcast, live, the guided conversations facilitated by Jean Lloyd. The project provides a safe space where participants on both sides of this conflict engage in a process that can alter the language and mindset of conflict to one of cooperation. Seeming adversaries will begin to understand one another on much deeper levels, creating partnership where none existed. The next Town Hall Meeting is scheduled for Monday, May 18 at 7 pm in Baltimore, MD. Please visit www.capsoc.info for more information.

Supplementing these Town Hall Meetings is our Public Education Campaign to spread the word and enlist others to get involved. We will sign up community groups, businesses, and leaders as members, sponsors, and key supporters to generate momentum to achieve the goals of the partnership. Our educational resources under development include a documentary about the work, PSAs, and other media promoting the work of CAPSOC.

Expected Results: A critical mass of committed individuals, community groups, religious institutions, and businesses, who generate the partnership with law enforcement sets the foundation to work together powerfully, forging an action agenda that will manifest in strategies governing police conduct. Concomitantly, as this partnership works to eliminate the violence perpetrated by law enforcement, perhaps the community can come to a higher truth that resolves to reduce the violence we perpetrate on ourselves. The possibilities are limitless for new conversations leading to taking on other community challenges, such as improving schools, creating more programs for our youth, supporting our seniors. Anything is possible in communication!

What We Need & What You Get

What We Need:Our aim is to raise $75,000 in the next 90 days, which represents 42% of our annual budget ($180,000). In the next 30 days we expect to raise the first $25,000. With this we can cover expenses for the second and third Town Hall Meetings and launch our Public Education Campaign. The first Town Hall meeting was completed thanks to the in-kind contributions of many individuals who have joined this effort and gave their blood, sweat and tears for strategic planning, marketing, production, broadcast, outreach, fundraising and facilitation expenses. The budget breakdown is as follows:

Town Hall Meetings (facilitation, technical/production team, facilities, equipment)

$45,000

Public Education and Ambassadors Campaign (documentary/PSA development, print and electronic materials, travel, media buys)      

$20,000

Fundraising Expenses (events, materials, mailing, perks)

$7,500

Administrative Expenses            

$2,500

Total= $75,000 

What You Get:In return for your contributions, we have many perks for you to enjoy Please look at the list of perks in that section. 

What happens if we have a money shortfall: Your contribution makes it possible for us to promote and produce the Town Hall meetings, engaging both law enforcement and communities who feel besieged by wanton violence; your support makes it possible to reach out to people across the DC region, as well as across the country. The only thing that may need adjustment is the timeframe of our events, if we don’t meet our fundraising benchmarks. However, we envision tremendous growth in numbers joining this initiative. Our fundraising will increase as the number of sponsors, friends, and members swell.

The Impact

The potential impact of CAPSOC can be far reaching. The first Town Hall meeting had participants reflecting on their own participation in community building and committing to the work of CAPSOC with others. Together we can find solutions that calls all of us to become responsible for the condition of our communities, and commit to building a shared vision that includes law enforcement.

The road to this transformation happens because we are creating a new model of communication which allows us to look at each other anew, especially those whom we viewed as our adversaries. The impact of the mass movement we are launching is significant progress forward toward reconciliation, compassion, and cooperation for a future in which we can all thrive.

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge is being able to reach a critical mass and a level of momentum that will make a difference. We started as two friends who said “we need to DO SOMETHING!” Now we’re fifty. Every day more individuals are coming forward, joining our efforts for peace on the streets. With your help our ranks will reach thousands. The goal is much bigger than any of our personal concerns; we are committed to success. Our lives and the lives of our children depend on this.

Other Ways You Can Help

You are someone who can make a difference with your contribution in time and commitment. Please consider joining us. Go to www.capsoc.info and sign up

  •   Attend a Town Hall Meeting, or
  •   Watch the live webcast and invite your friends and family to watch with you
  •   Share with your religious institutions, businesses, and social clubs; help recruit sponsors.
  •   Visit our website often for updates on our progress Creating a Profound Sense of Community
story_txt:
Overview
Creating
a Profound Sense of Community is a movement rising up in the wake of
recent tragedies inFerguson MO, Madison WI, Los Angeles CA, North
Charleston SC--and now Baltimore, MD. We have initiated this project to: 
·Dismantle
the barriers between law enforcement and the communities they serve that have
contributed to the use of excessive force and violence in our communities
·Create
partnerships in our communities, and with law enforcement to generate trust,
respect and honor to work together powerfully toward viable and acceptable
solutions
The goal of this campaign is to raise $75,000 for Town Hall
meetings and the Public Education Campaign.
Background
Who we are: We are Omar Henderson and Kareem Ali,
longtime residents of metropolitan Washington DC and partners in a media
company. We are parents and grandparents, and our deepest aspiration is that
our children—and all of the children in our communities—are safe and grow up to
become adults with productive and meaningful lives. We were profoundly
frustrated with the news of the Grand Jury’s failure to bring forward an
indictment of the police officer who shot and killed unarmed Michael Brown in
Ferguson, MO. Yet out of this sense of helplessness, we committed to do
something about this. We could no longer sit on the sidelines and complain and
we started Creating a Profound Sense of Community.

Why this project: We are all too familiar with the abuse, injury,
sense of victimization, even death from the use of excessive force in
encounters with police. At the same time, police officers we know say how
dangerous it is patrolling the streets in high crime areas. In Baltimore, more
than seven police officers were injured in the riots following the funeral of
latest police violence victim, Freddie Gray. The relationship between law
enforcement and the African Americans is laden with fear. The media
coverage exploits that emotion and sensationalizes the situation, leaving us
with a “well, what can we really do?”

What We Believe: Many policy suggestions are flying around, from
heightened accountability of law enforcement agencies, revision of regulations
governing police conduct, expanding the use of bodycams, and more. While all
these proposals hit at much needed reform, how do we move forward, in this
climate of mistrust, anger, and sorrow on a massive community level? We hear of
marches being organized to protest police violence and, while we truly want our
voices to be heard, the ensuing rioting overshadows our voices. What happens
after the destruction from the rioting? How are we going to forge a lasting
capacity to bring peace to our streets?
We firmly believe that partnership
between law enforcement and our communities is a necessity. Perhaps together we
can build trust, get to know one another on a deeper level and work together
powerfully to keep our streets safe. A climate of cooperation can help lay the
foundation on which new policies and regulations governing police conduct can
be built. AND we have to look at ourselves! Who are we that this
goes on in our communities? All of us need to take ownership
of our collective future. Creating a Profound Sense of Community
is an expression of our concern and compassion for people here and around
the world. 
When we can see one another as human
beings with fundamentally the same interests, we can work together instead of
resorting to violence out of fear and anger. Relationships can be transformed
and paradigm shifts will occur inside of new possibilities for collaboration. 
Building a Team:  We reached out to an international expert on conflict
resolution (featured in the national best-selling book, The Three Laws of Performance by Steve Zaffron) who is a
well-known leader in communication training and personal development, Ms. Jean
Lloyd. In 25 years as a change maker she has touched over 250,000 lives through
her work with corporations, non-profit organizations and individuals. She
calls herself a cultural architect instigating change and leading difficult
conversations that create cultures where everyone wins.
Upon receiving our invitation to
serve, Ms. Jean Lloyd enthusiastically accepted our request to facilitate the
town hall meetings. “No one has asked for my help to take on anything of this
magnitude and importance. I had to accept.” (For a fuller bio on Ms. Lloyd go
to http://jeanlloyd.com)
Subsequently we reached out to known
experts, professionals, and community leaders and formed teams around video and
broadcast production, strategic planning, finance, fundraising and non-profit
management, marketing and promotion.
The Project
The core activities: Creating a Profound Sense of
Community (CAPSOC) will host four “town hall’ style meetings to bring community
and law enforcement together.  CAPSOC meetings will broadcast, live, the
guided conversations facilitated by Jean Lloyd. The project provides a safe
space where participants on both sides of this conflict engage in a process
that can alter the language and mindset of conflict to one of cooperation. Seeming adversaries will begin to understand
one another on much deeper levels, creating partnership where none existed. The
next Town Hall Meeting is scheduled for Monday, May 18 at 7 pm in Baltimore,
MD. Please visit www.capsoc.info
for more information.
Supplementing these Town Hall
Meetings is our Public Education Campaign to spread the word and enlist others
to get involved. We will sign up community groups, businesses, and leaders as
members, sponsors, and key supporters to generate momentum to achieve the goals
of the partnership. Our educational resources under development include a
documentary about the work, PSAs, and other media promoting the work of CAPSOC.
Expected Results: A critical mass of committed individuals, community groups,
religious institutions, and businesses, who generate the partnership with law
enforcement sets the foundation to work together powerfully, forging an action
agenda that will manifest in strategies governing police conduct. Concomitantly,
as this partnership works to eliminate the violence perpetrated by law
enforcement, perhaps the community can come to a higher truth that resolves to
reduce the violence we perpetrate on ourselves. The possibilities are limitless
for new conversations leading to taking on other community challenges, such as
improving schools, creating more programs for our youth, supporting our
seniors. Anything is possible in communication!
What We Need & What You Get
What We Need:Our aim is to
raise $75,000 in the next 90 days, which represents 42% of our annual budget
($180,000). In the next 30 days we expect to raise the first $25,000. With this
we can cover expenses for the second and third Town Hall Meetings and launch
our Public Education Campaign. The first Town Hall meeting was completed thanks
to the in-kind contributions of many individuals who have joined this effort
and gave their blood, sweat and tears for strategic planning, marketing,
production, broadcast, outreach, fundraising and facilitation expenses. The
budget breakdown is as follows:
Town Hall Meetings (facilitation, technical/production team, facilities,
equipment) 
$45,000
Public Education and Ambassadors
Campaign (documentary/PSA development, print
and electronic materials, travel, media buys)      
$20,000
Fundraising Expenses (events, materials, mailing, perks) 
$7,500
Administrative Expenses  
         
$2,500
Total= $75,000 
What You Get:In return for
your contributions, we have many perks for you to enjoy Please look at the list
of perks in that section. 
What happens if we have a money
shortfall: Your contribution makes it possible
for us to promote and produce the Town Hall meetings, engaging both law
enforcement and communities who feel besieged by wanton violence; your support
makes it possible to reach out to people across the DC region, as well as
across the country. The only thing that may need adjustment is the timeframe of
our events, if we don’t meet our fundraising benchmarks. However, we envision
tremendous growth in numbers joining this initiative. Our fundraising will
increase as the number of sponsors, friends, and members swell.
The Impact
The potential impact of CAPSOC can
be far reaching. The first Town Hall meeting had participants reflecting on
their own participation in community building and committing to the work of
CAPSOC with others. Together we can find solutions that calls all of us to
become responsible for the condition of our communities, and commit to building
a shared vision that includes law enforcement.
The road to this transformation
happens because we are creating a new model of communication which allows us to
look at each other anew, especially those whom we viewed as our adversaries.
The impact of the mass movement we are launching is significant progress
forward toward reconciliation, compassion, and cooperation for a future in
which we can all thrive.
Risks & Challenges
The biggest challenge is being able
to reach a critical mass and a level of momentum that will make a difference.
We started as two friends who said “we need to DO SOMETHING!” Now we’re fifty.
Every day more individuals are coming forward, joining our efforts for peace on
the streets. With your help our ranks will reach thousands. The goal is much
bigger than any of our personal concerns; we are committed to success. Our
lives and the lives of our children depend on this.
Other Ways You Can Help
You are someone who can make a
difference with your contribution in time and commitment. Please consider
joining us. Go to www.capsoc.info and sign up


  Attend a Town Hall Meeting, or

  Watch the live webcast and invite your friends and family to
watch with you

  Share with your religious institutions, businesses, and
social clubs; help recruit sponsors.

  Visit our website often for updates on our progress Creating
a Profound Sense of Community

story:
We are the Spikes' (Fredrick & Tynesha) and we are the owners of Sno Tasty Treats and Eats. We're a small mom and pop business looking to expand. We are both college graduates and have 4 kids all under the age of 7. Despite our busy days and both having full time jobs; starting a business has always been our dream. Our kids love snow cones and it's pretty hard to deny the smiles when they have them; ultimately we decided to make it a business. As an educator of 11-years (Tynesha) I want to give back to students, their parents, and our community, We want to create jobs and create smiles day to day! 

We currently have a trailer that travels throughout Houston and surrounding areas. We're planning to open a permanent location for the summer. We need funds to help furnish the building, equipment, and hire full-time employees. (We hire single moms, Veterans, and teens looking for work, anyone who needs a break and looking for work)

We are hoping to raise $30,000 of the start-up cost to make the extension of our business dream a reality. With the help of others we could put a smile to every passer by. We have put our all so far in our business, we've skipped out on home/car improvements and family vacations knowing that our four kids will reap the benefits one day and with the power of a supported community we can do just that.  We are inspired to keep working forward and feel blessed to have such a wonderful group of people surrounding us. 

If you haven't already, please share our campaign with your network & Sno contribute today!

With gratitude, 

Fredrick & Tynesha

story:
Short Summary

I am launching Creative Innovation Consulting, an inexpensive consulting firm which specializes in scientific, business and legal consulting. My target market is the young at heart Entrepreneur who wants to get her/his business going but isn't sure how and doesn't have a lot of money to get professional advice. Consulting services in the areas of science, business and law can go for up to $1000.00 an hour, a price no new Entrepreneur can really afford. My service will provide consulting for a quarter of that price, and on a sliding scale if needed. Why do I do it? Because I love to develop new ideas and by working with these young inventors and business people I get to develop more ideas than I could have in a lifetime!

What We Need & What You Get

I am hoping to raise $30,000.00 for two specific purposes. First, I want to have a launch event which will allow me to get the word out to young Entrepreneurs (not just the investor crowd etc) about a place they can go to get help starting their businesses. This event would be held in Boston, MA on New Year's Eve, welcoming in 2016 at one of the local hotel venues or perhaps a historical site. The event would be both a way to introduce Entrepreneurs to Creative Innovation Consulting but I will also bring in a number of industry leaders so the event will also serve as a networking platform for the Entrepreneurs. The event is slated to cost about $24,,000 which will cover the cost of the venue, the food, the speaker fees and help underwrite a small number of hotel rooms for young Entrepreneurs that would not otherwise be able to attend. 

The rest of the money would be used to expand my social and market presence to make more Entrepreneurs aware of this lost cost option to help get them started. Money would be spent on developing an interactive IT platform so that I can work with Entrepreneurs that are not located in the Boston, Massachusetts area.


The Impact

I have my PhD in Neuroscience from Albert Einstein College of Medicine. My first faculty position was at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons. I was recruited to Harvard Medical School in 2008 and spent many years running my own laboratory focusing on cardiovascular disease. I then left Harvard and went back to school to get my Juris Doctor. My specialty is Intellectual Property and I have worked for the past years with Entrepreneurs, helping them get started and helping them protect their intellectual property. I presently work with MassBio helping advise young inventors with development of their projects. 


What I have found is that most young companies get in to trouble with contracts and intellectual property issues early because as they start up they cannot afford to hire Attorneys or Business Consultants. They try to do it all on their own, usually with unfortunate results. I work with clients who find themselves embroiled in lawsuits based on issues they did not get help with early and now they are paying the price. Some of these companies have truly amazing technology that is lost to the public when the company goes under due to poor strategy or legal protection. 


I want to end this problem by making a place for these Entrepreneurs to come to for help. 


Risks & Challenges

It is always risky to start a new business, and Entrepreneurs know this! One risk here is that even with the lower charges than a standard consulting firm a really young company, say one person with a great idea, would still not be able to afford the service. I plan to mitigate this risk by affiliating with a local pro bono Intellectual Property and Entrepreneurship clinic where I could send clients for help if they cannot afford my services. I also plan to offer a sliding scale fee system to help Entrepreneurs afford the help they need. 

Another challenge is that while I have a lot of experience, I do not know everything! There will be things that people need that I am not able to help with. To mitigate this problem I have developed relationships with individuals in other related fields that I can go to for help, or can send clients to if the situation is too complex. 

There will always be a few challenges but I know I can rise to them and really solve the problem of affordable advice. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you know of someone who needs help starting a business, particularly (but not limited to) biotechnology, technology or other technical field, please let them know where they can find help, here at Creative Innovation Consulting!

story:
About Right Bee Cider:

Brewer meets girl. Brewer makes cider to woo girl. It worked. Right Beside Her. RIGHT BEE CIDER.

In 2012, Charlie Davis made Katie Morgan a hard cider for her birthday. Shortly after, they started dating, and got married May 17, 2014. Right Bee Cider was officially launched six months later.

Meet the Team:

We are a husband-and-wife duo creating a delicious, unfiltered, unique hard cider in the Chicago area. We are currently on tap at 28 locations around Chicago (and counting!). With just TWO people, we've done everything from licensing, trademarking, permitting, developing procedures, business organization, planning the premises, designing the logo, to hand making our taphandles, in addition to making a delicious hard cider, of course!

  • Worker Bee: Charlie Davis - Co-Founder/Co-Owner
  • 6 years in the professional craft brewing world
  • Gold and Silver medal winning recipes
  • Aided in the start of 4 craft breweries
  • Built RBC's outdoor cooler, keg washer, and many other materials by hand
  • Has a very impressive beard
  • Manages ALL cider operations

  • Queen Bee: Katie Morgan - Co-Founder/Co-Owner
  • 100% success rate at tastings
  • Manages ALL bookkeeping, invoices, scheduling, PR, marketing, social media, account relations, events, and administration
  • Makes homemade and hand-painted taphandles

  • Norm: Bright Yellow Pick-Up Truck
  • Helps us deliver kegs around Chicago
  • Increases the 'cool factor' of everyone around him by at LEAST 80%


Our Cider:

- Unfiltered
- 5.7% ABV- Description: Crisp, Tart, Dry, and Refreshing
- All natural: No synthetic or artificial sweeteners or colors
- Ingredients - Apples, yeast (for fermentation), organic, fair trade, unrefined cane     sugar
- Gluten-free

WHY we need help:

  • Our process is tedious and cumbersome with our current space and equipment
  •  It takes us 8-10 hours to complete tasks that could take MINUTES with new equipment
  • We currently use space heaters instead of temperature controlled equipment to ferment our cider, which makes consistency challenging.
  • We work outside during Chicago's winter. This led to: frozen locks, power outages, and frozen limbs. Our outdoor cooler was buried in a 10 ft snowdrift, which we dug out BY HAND in order to make deliveries. We have countless stories like this. Working outside in the winter makes our procedure incredibly difficult and unsafe.
  • Norm, our bright yellow delivery truck, is going to need all four tires replaced 

WHAT will your donation do?

We would be so grateful if YOU could help us! Anything and everything will make a HUGE impact.

  • Expansion will allow us to increase our production and keep up with demand
  • More kegs will help us self-distribute to more locations throughout Chicago
  • Temperature controlled tanks will help us create a consistent product
  • New equipment will streamline our process and make our procedure SAFER
  • Norm, our delivery truck, will get new tires!
  • **EXCEEDING our fundraising goal would allow us to seek new space, and move towards our ultimate goal of a taproom where YOU can enjoy our cider on site!**

Accomplishments/Press

  • Featured on the COVER of the RedEye
  • Featured speakers at Chicago's Taste Talks event
  • Winner: Sam Adams Pitch Room Competition
  • Featured in Crain's Business Chicago
  • Featured in The Chicagoist

Can't donate? No problem! Help us spread the BUZZ!

  • Share our crowdfunding campaign with family and friends
  • Follow us on social media and like our posts!
  • Facebook: www.facebook.com/rightbeecider
  • Instagram: @rightbee_cider
  • Twitter: @rightbeecider
  • Chicagoans: Head to our accounts for some pints, attend our events, and tell your favorite bars and restaurants about us


Our cider brought us together, and with your help, we can continue to bring others together. We are so thankful for your love and support!

story:
A little introduction...

Hello! I am Bonnie  - the 'B' in Sweet B's. Food is my passion, specifically when it comes to sweets. I am trained (Georgian College Culinary - shout out!) and well versed in all that is sweet.  I have been running a dessert catering business based out of Bradford through the use of rented kitchen space. The time has come where Sweet B's needs a space to call its own!  I have grown up in Bradford and am very proud to call it home.  Opening this shop anywhere else is not an option. 

To learn more about the products Sweet B's offers, check out www.SweetB.ca.  You'll be drooling your way all the way to the 'contribute now' button :)


Where your money will go...

The location has been picked, the layout has been designed, the contractors have been hired, the menu is made and the recipes are perfected...but I'm a little short when it comes to what I need to get the doors open.  That's where you come in.

My goal is $10,000 which would be used to renovate and construct my chosen space (which is right in the heart of Bradford) to turn it into a bakeshop specializing in cakes, cupcakes, candies and all sorts of unique homemade desserts.   The design itself is very open concept allowing our customers to take part in the experience of witnessing handcrafted sweets made right before your eyes.  Even the front window will be transformed into a decorating area.  Sweet B's will be not just a bakeshop, it will be an experience for the whole family to enjoy.  

What you'll get...

Who doesn't like a sweet treat?  Check out the 'perks' section to see what each donation level will entitle you to receive.  The lowest level is $5, which will get you a free cupcake at our Grand Opening celebration.  The highest level is $500, which would include ALL of the lower level perks as well as the opportunity to have us raise money for a charity of your choice,  This particular incentive is an extension of the 'Cakes for a Cause' program we ran in December 2014, where a Sweet B's speciality cake was auctioned off with 100% of the proceeds going to a local charity (see below, an example of the cake I auctioned off for the MS Society).  Programs like 'Cakes for a Cause' are very important to me and I look forward to having the means to do even more for the community.

How can we make this happen?

My Facebook page www.facebook.com/SweetBs.confectionery is the best place to see what Sweet B's is up to - promotions, photos, events.  I have a very supportive online fan base, and am pleading for help from those people - YOU!   In fact, if each person who 'likes' my Facebook page were to donate $20 (in exchange for 1/2 dozen cupcakes at my Grand Opening celebration!  see the 'perks'...)  I would not only meet my goal - I would greatly surpass it. 

No money?  No problem...

 If you can't donate anything to my campaign, I completely understand.  All I ask is you share this campain with your friends, family, coworkers...anyone!    Any little bit of support helps, monetary or otherwise and I appreciate every last ounce of it.

Thank you, thank you..THANK YOU!

I am forever grateful for the help, support and kind words coming in.  I could not do it without you.  Thank you for helping this dream come true, for myself and my family.

P.S.  Here is a little slideshow of some of my work... enjoy!
story_txt: A little introduction...Hello!  I am Bonnie  - the 'B' in Sweet B's.   Food is my passion, specifically when it comes to sweets.  I am trained (Georgian College Culinary - shout out!) and well versed in all that is sweet.  I have been running a dessert catering business based out of Bradford through the use of rented kitchen space.   The time has come where Sweet B's needs a space to call its own!  I have grown up in Bradford and am very proud to call it home.  Opening this shop anywhere else is not an option.  To learn more about the products Sweet B's offers, check out www.SweetB.ca.  You'll be drooling your way all the way to the 'contribute now' button :)Where your money will go...The location has been picked, the layout has been designed, the contractors have been hired, the menu is made and the recipes are perfected...but I'm a little short when it comes to what I need to get the doors open.  That's where you come in.My goal is $10,000 which would be used to renovate and construct my chosen space (which is right in the heart of Bradford) to turn it into a bakeshop specializing in cakes, cupcakes, candies and all sorts of unique homemade desserts.   The design itself is very open concept allowing our customers to take part in the experience of witnessing handcrafted sweets made right before your eyes.  Even the front window will be transformed into a decorating area.  Sweet B's will be not just a bakeshop, it will be an experience for the whole family to enjoy.   What you'll get...Who doesn't like a sweet treat?  Check out the 'perks' section to see what each donation level will entitle you to receive.  The lowest level is $5, which will get you a free cupcake at our Grand Opening celebration.  The highest level is $500, which would include ALL of the lower level perks as well as the opportunity to have us raise money for a charity of your choice,  This particular incentive is an extension of the 'Cakes for a Cause' program we ran in December 2014, where a Sweet B's speciality cake was auctioned off with 100% of the proceeds going to a local charity (see below, an example of the cake I auctioned off for the MS Society).  Programs like 'Cakes for a Cause' are very important to me and I look forward to having the means to do even more for the community.How can we make this happen?My Facebook page www.facebook.com/SweetBs.confectionery is the best place to see what Sweet B's is up to - promotions, photos, events.  I have a very supportive online fan base, and am pleading for help enjoy!

story:
Short Summary

The Inter Council for Mothers of Murdered Children is an Organization formed by Anita Wills and Dionne Smith-Downs in 2013. Anita Wills is a Community Activist, whose 19 year old grandson was killed in January of 2011. She is also on the Advisory Council for the Essie Justice Group.  Dionne Smith-Downs is a Community Activist in Stockton California and throughout the Bay Area.  She and her family suffered the loss of their 16 year old son in 2010.  

There is an epidemic of violence in our community resulting in families devastated and left to grieve alone. The Inter Council for Mothers of Murdered Children offers assistance to families through Peer Counseling, Referrals, and other support service. Our goal is to contact and assist families who may not receive traditional support. This involves traveling to the scene of crimes and assisting family members and others in the community.  In order to meet our goal we have a Community Service Van Program (CSV). This program features a van that is fully equipped (like an office on wheels), to assist those in need.  We will be on the scene to gather pertinent information regarding the victim, and circumstances in order to assist the family. The Van will be equipped with Computers, video equipment, telephones, information,and emergency supplies for families. Your donation will help us in our campaign to purchase and equip the vehicle. 

Your contributions will help us fulfill our Mission of providing services to families who are falling through the crack. We have families of murder victims who, after the loss of a family, have come under scrutiny, lost their incomes, and homes. They receive little support or counseling for their murdered loved ones. We intend to fill that gap and your donation will help! 

This is why your valuable contribution is appreciated!

 We are seeking $10000 to purchase and equip ICMMC's, first Community Service Mobil Van.  Any and all donors will be acknowledged through our website, Social Media Pages, and on Print Material (unless otherwise requested). Please see our Perks Page for other items and acknowledgements!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot donate, please get the word out and make noise about our Campaign, using the Indiegogo Share tools.

story:
Kamm and Indey took over Cigars Boots & Chocolate (Baltimore) in October 2013. Over the last year and a half they have grown CBC from a small, intimate social to a larger safe space for the kink and queer communities. CBC provides free cigars for our patrons as well as any accessories such as torches, cutters, ash trays and cigar holders.

We host anywhere from 20-30 socials a year, with our busy season covering at least 20 socials at various events and venues throughout the District, Maryland and Virginia areas. Covering cigars alone for this amount of events is daunting. We have gone through over 100 cigars for a single social alone. While we do accept donations and appreciate each that we receive, donations we have received do not come close to covering what Kamm and Indey have put in to keep CBC operating at the level our patrons are used to. 

We're hoping you can help us cover some of our expenses for the 2015 season.

Money raised would go towards procuring more cigars (250-500 cigars), accessories to replace some items that have been lost or broken (torches, butane, cutters, etc), entry fees for some of our staff to events that may not be able to grant all 3 of us entry and a new CBC sign featuring our new logo.

story:
Cliquer ICI pour la version en français

You can like my Facebook page https://www.facebook.com/tabersnackPEC

Why I Need Your Help? "I Have A Dream…"

That I will make a living doing what I love. I love cooking! It’s my passion.

But…starting a new business requires lots of funds.

In order to have a loan for the purchase of the Tabersnack food truck, any financial institution is asking that I have a $10 000 cash deposit. This is where I need your help with this fundraiser.

Below you will find the details of some of the different costs I will incur to start my journey. I am sure there will be more, but for now, here are the ones I know as a fact!

Cost Details

Cost of the food truck: $81 000

Re-zoning Fees: $867 (minimum)

Kitchen Equipment: $5 000

Marketing - website, logo, card, rack cards, etc.: $4 000 (I know, it's small but I have to start somewhere).

Point of sale and electronics: $1 000

Indiegogo Fees: Indiegogo charges a 4% fee if I reach my goal. On top of that, they are charging 3.5% to cover the Paypal fees. If I don’t reach the goal they take 9%... but let's not go there, right?

One more important thing about this fundraiser... Whatever the amount I am able to raise, I am making a promise to myself that I WILL HAVE that food truck, no matter what!

A Little Bit About Me

For as long as I can remember, cooking has been a real passion for me. The love and passion for food  is running through my blood! After thinking about it a little bit, I understand why it is in my genes! Both of my grandfathers were cooks and earned their living this way. For a few years, my mom was the chef in a pizzeria our family owned. Two of her brothers were chefs their entire lives. Again, the same thing on my dad’s side. Three of his siblings were professional cooks and two of my cousins work as chefs. All of them are self-taught cooks. Well I guess this is why my desire to cook is so strong. It is in me!

As many of you may know, I am French Canadian. I moved from Quebec city in 1998 to go to the big city, Montreal. From there, I moved to the Cayman Islands in 2009 and one year later, I moved to Prince Edward County! Yup, I left the Caribbean to come to the beautiful county; a small peninsula on the  Lake Ontario. One of the best decisions I have ever made! Now, 4 years later, I thought that the County could benefit from a little blend of Quebec, Montreal, Caribbean and county food flair!

I have been working in sales for 19 years and have worked in an office environment for all my adult life. I love helping people so it was good, but it’s far from being in a kitchen, where I really want to be! I have never been a big recipe follower. I just go with my instinct, and not too often has my instinct failed me. I love smelling ingredients. Just by the smell, I will know what works with what. For me it’s easy. Just like it is easy for some artists to take a paint brush and start painting.

This past October, I participated in my first "cook off" at the Wellington Farmer's market, in Prince Edward County. I thought to myself, why not give it a try and participate. To my astonishment, I won the first prize! This was a revelation to me. On that same day, just for fun, I brought with me some sweet pickled beets and sweet and spicy pickled onions to sell. I was surprised by people’s reaction. They loved them and were saying they tasted like beets they tried in Quebec!! This is where I got the idea of a food truck.

Location! Location! Location!

My ultimate goal is to be able to have my own food truck on my property but also be able to move around and get to festivals and events. In summer and winter I would like to stay stationary on North Beach road (where I reside).  Many people use this road to go to the beach and to get to some local campgrounds. Also, in my area, I am surrounded by wineries, farms, and beautiful tourist destinations. For spring and fall, I would be “on the go” to different fairs, festivals and trade shows in the area. With so many things happening in the county for spring and fall, you won’t want to miss it!

Prince Edward County is located 1 hour south-west of Kingston, 4 hours west from Montreal or Ottawa or 2 hours east from Toronto. The County, like the locals are calling it, is well known for its agro-tourism, its white sand beaches (Sandbanks Provincial Park, Presqu’Ile Provincial Park and North Beach Provincial Park) and the diversity of artists. It is still small enough to call it country but big enough to have a great time.

Why do I want to be open during winter? Well… anybody who knows the area knows that it’s hard to find a place to eat lunch during the low tourist season.  Because I care about the well being of the locals, this is the reason why I want to be open on weekdays for lunch during the cold season. There won't be any need to drive at least 20 minutes to find food in Hillier! Weekly menu and specials will be posted on Facebook and Twitter! On request, catering will also be available.

The Food!

I have so many ideas that I am having a hard time setting a fixed menu! So it will change from time to time to be able to offer different types of food!

One thing is for sure, I want to “rock your socks off” with my jerk chicken and jerk tofu! Yup! You read it right, tofu! I have to have something for everybody, right? Of course, I will have poutine. How I could not have poutine if I am coming from Quebec city? I want your mouth to squeak while eating it!

Otherwise, here are some examples of what I would like to cook for you in the summer. I am always open to suggestions!

·  Burgers

·  Blooming onions (small and colossal family size) and onion rings

·  Guedille (kind of a lobster roll but with chicken or egg salad

·  Cipaille or tourtière (meat pie but with cubed meat)

·  Panini

·  Maple anything! Like Maple pie, “Pouding chômeur”, salad dressing, maple glazed pork, maple ham, etc!

·  Homemade potato chips and French fries

·  Vegetarian and Vegan options

·  Sweet treats (cookies, vegan bars, cakes, puddings, etc.)

·  And much more!

The menu will be slightly different during the “cold” season as I want to make sure to warm you up to the bone. For sure the staples like poutine and burgers will stay on the menu but I would like to get more into comfort food like stews, braised meat of some sort, shepherd’s pie, earthy soups, desserts, etc.

You tell me what you would like to get and I will give it my best to make it happen. The ideas are limitless and I will change with the seasons to give you the freshest most delicious food truck food you’ve ever had.

In The County, For The County, With The County
I will, as much as possible, be as green as I can be. I have already sourced many ingredient suppliers that are local, like the cheese, meat, fruits, vegetables and coffee (which is roasted in the county). All of the utensils that customers use will be made out of vegetable starch, a highly compostable material. Only cardboard containers will be used to serve the food. I promise that you won't see any styrofoam containers being used in the food truck!  Also, a pig farmer close by was delighted to know that I will be giving them all of my vegetable waste so they can feed the pigs with fresh food.

What I Plan To Do This Season

Hopefully, the truck will be ready for August of this year! I hope to be able to order the food truck by the end of April. Did you know that it takes approximately 4 months for a food truck to be ready?!? While waiting for the truck to be ready for me, I will work on my canned goods and pre-made items to be ready for the Farmer’s market season. Wellington, Trenton and Belleville, wait for me, I’m on my way to your market with my jars!

I also plan on working as much as possible on different ways to market Tabersnack! I want people to know me even before I am open for business with my truck! I really hope I won’t have to wait until August to have the truck, or I might go bananas! And when I have my truck, you will hear from me for sure! As soon as I have it, I will be open to fill you up until you drop (almost). I sure hope you will want to stop by over and over again. I am looking forward to that day, but meanwhile, I will enjoy preparing this upcoming spring and early summer.

THANK YOU!

I cook with love and passion and I want to serve every customer as if they were friends eating at my kitchen table. Achieving this will make me very happy!

Your generosity is greatly appreciated and I want to thank each and every one of you from the bottom of my heart.  I am looking forward to being overwhelmed with joy while I cook for you. I know I’ll make you happy by serving you food that will make you smile and make your mouth water until the last bite!

Thank you so much for believing in me and helping my dream to become a reality.

A bientôt!
